explanation:
Correct calculation: \( 2 \div \frac{1}{5} = 2 \times \frac{5}{1} = 10 \).

Student's error: Likely computed \( \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{5} = \frac{1}{10} \), taking the reciprocal of the dividend (2) instead of the divisor (\(\frac{1}{5}\)).

The student inverted the first number (2) rather than the second (\(\frac{1}{5}\)), converting division into \( \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{5} \) instead of \( 2 \times 5 \). This reflects a direct inversion of the wrong term in the division expression.

This differs from order reversal (which would require writing \(\frac{1}{5} \div 2\)) or reciprocal of both fractions (which would produce \(\frac{1}{2} \times 5 = \frac{5}{2}\)). The error specifically stems from misidentifying which fraction requires reciprocal when converting division to multiplication.
